article.head: Climate Action Note – Climate Action progress

text.p: Global temperatures are linked to the concentration of greenhouse gases (GHG) in our atmosphere and we are heading for a catastrophic rise in excess of 3°C this century. To limit this to 1.5°C, we need to cut emissions by 30 gigatones annually by 2030. That means cutting emissions from transport and industry, managing land and resources more efficiently, building smart cities and curbing deforestation and food waste. The world has to move towards net-zero emissions soon - and start moving now.
The UNEP Climate ActionDashboard shows you the global state of climate action and where each country has work to do.[a][b]

article.title: Net zero targets
article.head: Countries must strengthen pledges and actions to reach the Paris Agreement goal

text.p: In the Paris Agreement, governments pledged to contribute - so-called Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) to cut emissions. More and more countries are committing to net-zero emissions targets yet ambition needs to be tripled for the 2°C pathway and increased fivefold for the 1.5°C pathway. article.title: NDC
article.head: Countries must strengthen pledges made under Paris Agreement

text.p: Under the 2015 Paris Agreement, governments made pledges, known as Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs), to cut emissions. And although a growing number of countries have now committed to net-zero emissions, the levels of ambition in the Paris accord must be roughly tripled for the 2°C pathway and increased at least fivefold for the 1.5°C pathway. There is no time to lose.

Global temperatures are linked to the concentration of greenhouse gases (GHG) in our atmosphere and we are heading for a catastrophic rise in excess of 3°C this century. To limit this to 1.5°C, we need to cut emissions by 30 gigatones annually by 2030. There is popular support for such emission reductions and to act ambitiously and adequately on the climate emergency.
Data for the net-zero targets pledged by countries comes from Net Zero Tracker. Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit, Data-Driven EnviroLab, NewClimate Institute, Oxford Net Zero. 2021.
Data for the public opinion section comes from Pew Research Center, February, 2019, “Climate Change Still Seen as the Top Global Threat, but Cyberattacks a Rising Concern”
Data for the NDC pledges comes from Climate Watch. 2020. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute.

Data for GHG emissions, used to size the countries in the net zero and NDC sections, comes from Crippa, M., Guizzardi, D., Solazzo, E., Muntean, M., Schaaf, E., Monforti-Ferrario, F., Banja, M., Olivier, J.G.J., Grassi, G., Rossi, S., Vignati, E., GHG emissions of all world countries - 2021 Report, EUR 30831 EN, Publications Office of the European Union, Luxembourg, 2021, ISBN 978-92-76-41547-3, doi:10.2760/173513, JRC126363

The “GHG emissions of all world countries - 2021 Report” uses the Emissions Database for Global Atmospheric Research, which groups certain countries for statistical reasons: Switzerland and Liechtenstein; Sudan and South Sudan; Spain and Andorra; Serbia and Montenegro; Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha; Italy, San Marino and the Holy See; Israel and State of Palestine; and France and Monaco.
